nodes.label: Pythagorean identity for sine ...
nodes.title: The fundamental trigonometric identity stating that the square of cosine plus the square of sine of an angle equals one.

nodes.label: Sine rule for triangle side ra...
nodes.title: A formula relating the ratios of sides of a triangle to the sines of their opposite angles.

nodes.label: Cosine rule for triangle side ...
nodes.title: A formula that relates the lengths of sides of a triangle to the cosine of one of its angles, useful for finding unknown sides or angles.

nodes.label: Cosine of angle difference for...
nodes.title: An identity expressing the cosine of the difference between two angles in terms of the cosines and sines of the individual angles.

nodes.label: Cosine of angle sum formula
nodes.title: An identity expressing the cosine of the sum of two angles in terms of the cosines and sines of the individual angles.

nodes.label: Double angle formula for cosin...
nodes.title: An identity expressing the cosine of twice an angle as the difference of the squares of cosine and sine of the angle.

nodes.label: Sine of angle sum formula
nodes.title: An identity expressing the sine of the sum of two angles in terms of the sines and cosines of the individual angles.

nodes.label: Sine of angle difference formu...
nodes.title: An identity expressing the sine of the difference between two angles in terms of the sines and cosines of the individual angles.

nodes.label: Tangent of angle sum formula
nodes.title: An identity expressing the tangent of the sum of two angles in terms of the tangents of the individual angles.

nodes.label: Tangent of angle difference fo...
nodes.title: An identity expressing the tangent of the difference between two angles in terms of the tangents of the individual angles.

nodes.label: Double angle formula for sine ...
nodes.title: An identity expressing the sine of twice an angle as twice the product of sine and cosine of the angle.

nodes.label: Double angle formula for tange...
nodes.title: An identity expressing the tangent of twice an angle in terms of the tangent of the angle.

nodes.label: Cosine squared in terms of cos...
nodes.title: An identity expressing the square of cosine of an angle as half the sum of one and the cosine of twice the angle.

nodes.label: Sine squared in terms of cosin...
nodes.title: An identity expressing the square of sine of an angle as half the difference of one and the cosine of twice the angle.

nodes.label: Product-to-sum formula for 2 c...
nodes.title: An identity expressing twice the product of cosines of two angles as the sum of cosines of their sum and difference.

nodes.label: Product-to-sum formula for 2 s...
nodes.title: An identity expressing twice the product of sine of one angle and cosine of another as the sum of sines of their sum and difference.

nodes.label: Product-to-sum formula for 2 s...
nodes.title: An identity expressing twice the product of sines of two angles as the difference of cosines of their difference and sum.

nodes.label: Product-to-sum formula for 2 c...
nodes.title: An identity expressing twice the product of cosine of one angle and sine of another as the difference of sines of their sum and difference.

nodes.label: Sum-to-product formula for cos...
nodes.title: An identity expressing the sum of cosines of two angles as twice the product of cosines of half their sum and half their difference.

nodes.label: Sum-to-product formula for cos...
nodes.title: An identity expressing the difference of cosines of two angles as negative twice the product of sines of half their sum and half their difference.

nodes.label: Sum-to-product formula for sin...
nodes.title: An identity expressing the sum of sines of two angles as twice the product of sines of half their sum and cosines of half their difference.

nodes.label: Sum-to-product formula for sin...
nodes.title: An identity expressing the difference of sines of two angles as twice the product of cosines of half their sum and sines of half their difference.

nodes.label: circle drawing with given radi...
nodes.title: Constructing a circle using a compass with a specified radius from a given center point.

nodes.label: use of straight edge in geomet...
nodes.title: Employing a straight edge tool to draw straight lines accurately in geometric diagrams.

nodes.label: use of compass in geometric co...
nodes.title: Using a compass to draw arcs and circles with precision in geometric diagrams.

nodes.label: use of ruler in geometric cons...
nodes.title: Applying a ruler to measure lengths and draw straight lines in geometric diagrams.

nodes.label: use of protractor in geometric...
nodes.title: Using a protractor to measure and construct specific angles in geometric diagrams.

nodes.label: use of set square in geometric...
nodes.title: Employing a set square to draw perpendicular and parallel lines accurately in geometric diagrams.

nodes.label: coordinating the plane
nodes.title: Assigning ordered pairs (x, y) to points in the plane to represent their positions numerically.

nodes.label: representing linear relationsh...
nodes.title: Organizing values of variables that satisfy a linear relationship into tables for analysis.

nodes.label: representing linear relationsh...
nodes.title: Plotting points on a coordinate plane to visualize linear relationships as straight lines.

nodes.label: equivalence of slope and rate ...
nodes.title: Understanding that the slope of a linear graph corresponds to the rate of change of the dependent variable with respect to the independent variable.

nodes.label: interpretation of start value ...
nodes.title: Recognizing the y-intercept as the initial value or starting point of a linear relationship in context.

nodes.label: point of intersection of two l...
nodes.title: The coordinate point where two linear graphs meet, representing the solution to the system of equations.

nodes.label: strategies for solving systems...
nodes.title: Using graphical, numeric, or mental methods to find solutions to problems involving two linear relationships.

nodes.label: Pythagorean theorem applicatio...
nodes.title: Using the relation a² + b² = c² to solve problems involving lengths in right-angled triangles, including heights and distances.

nodes.label: use of trigonometric ratios in...
nodes.title: Applying sine, cosine, and tangent ratios to find unknown sides or angles in right-angled triangles in real-world contexts.

nodes.label: identification of axes of symm...
nodes.title: Locating lines through shapes that divide them into mirror-image halves.

nodes.label: recognition of images under tr...
nodes.title: Understanding how points and objects shift uniformly in a given direction and distance without rotation or reflection.

nodes.label: recognition of images under ce...
nodes.title: Identifying points and objects reflected through a central point producing an image rotated 180 degrees about that point.

nodes.label: recognition of images under ax...
nodes.title: Identifying points and objects reflected across a line (axis of symmetry) producing mirror images.

nodes.label: recognition of images under ro...
nodes.title: Understanding how points and objects are turned about a fixed point through a specified angle and direction.

nodes.label: investigation of enlargements ...
nodes.title: Studying how enlargements with a given centre and scale factor affect the size and area of shapes, including scale factors less than 1 and greater than 1 (rational numbers).

nodes.label: performing geometric construct...
nodes.title: Executing specific geometric constructions numbered 16 through 21 as per referenced curriculum materials.

nodes.label: use of logic and deductive rea...
nodes.title: Understanding and applying terms such as theorem, proof, axiom, corollary, converse, implies, is equivalent to, if and only if, and proof by contradiction in geometric reasoning.

nodes.label: investigation and proof of the...
nodes.title: Studying and proving theorems concerning ratios that underpin the Pythagorean theorem and other geometric results.

nodes.label: use of slope to determine para...
nodes.title: Using the equality of slopes to establish that two lines are parallel.

nodes.label: use of slope to determine perp...
nodes.title: Using the negative reciprocal relationship of slopes to establish that two lines are perpendicular.

nodes.label: recognition of linear equation...
nodes.title: Understanding that equations of the form ax + by + c = 0 represent straight lines in the coordinate plane.

nodes.label: calculation of triangle area u...
nodes.title: Finding the area of a triangle given the coordinates of its vertices using coordinate geometry formulas.

edges.title: The double angle formula for cosine (cos 2A = cos²A – sin²A) directly uses the squares of sine and cosine, which are related by the Pythagorean identity.
Expressing cos²A in terms of cos 2A relies on the Pythagorean identity to relate sine squared and cosine squared.
Expressing sin²A in terms of cos 2A uses the Pythagorean identity to connect sine squared and cosine squared.

The cosine of angle difference formula is similar in form to the cosine of angle sum formula and can be derived using similar reasoning; the text lists the difference formula after the sum formula, implying the sum formula is foundational.
The sine of angle difference formula is closely related to the sine of angle sum formula and is listed after it, indicating the sum formula is a prerequisite.
The double angle formula for cosine can be derived by applying the cosine of angle sum formula with equal angles (A + A), so understanding the sum formula is necessary.
The double angle formula for sine is derived by applying the sine of angle sum formula with equal angles (A + A), so the sum formula is a prerequisite.
The tangent of angle difference formula is listed after the sum formula and is closely related, implying the sum formula is foundational for understanding the difference formula.
The double angle formula for tangent can be derived by applying the tangent of angle sum formula with equal angles (A + A), so the sum formula is a prerequisite.
The product-to-sum formula for 2 cos A cos B is expressed in terms of cos(A+B) and cos(A–B), so understanding the cosine sum formula is necessary.
Similarly, the product-to-sum formula for 2 cos A cos B depends on cos(A–B), so the cosine difference formula is also a prerequisite.
The product-to-sum formula for 2 sin A cos B is expressed in terms of sin(A+B) and sin(A–B), so understanding the sine sum formula is necessary.
Similarly, the product-to-sum formula for 2 sin A cos B depends on sin(A–B), so the sine difference formula is also a prerequisite.
The product-to-sum formula for 2 sin A sin B is expressed in terms of cos(A–B) and cos(A+B), so the cosine sum formula is necessary.
Similarly, the product-to-sum formula for 2 sin A sin B depends on cos(A–B), so the cosine difference formula is also a prerequisite.
The product-to-sum formula for 2 cos A sin B is expressed in terms of sin(A+B) and sin(A–B), so the sine sum formula is necessary.
Similarly, the product-to-sum formula for 2 cos A sin B depends on sin(A–B), so the sine difference formula is also a prerequisite.
The sum-to-product formula for cos A + cos B expresses the sum in terms of products of cosines of half-angles, which is conceptually related to product-to-sum formulas and likely builds on them.
The sum-to-product formula for cos A – cos B involves sines of half sums and differences, related to the product-to-sum identities involving sine products, indicating a prerequisite relationship.
The sum-to-product formula for sin A + sin B expresses the sum as products of sines and cosines of half angles, related to product-to-sum formulas involving sine and cosine products.
The sum-to-product formula for sin A – sin B expresses the difference as products of cosines and sines of half angles, related to product-to-sum formulas involving cosine and sine products.
The text lists the sine formula before the cosine formula and the cosine rule builds on understanding of triangle side ratios and angles, implying the sine rule is a prerequisite.
Drawing a circle of given radius requires using a compass, so understanding circle drawing is foundational to using the compass effectively in constructions.
Using a ruler to measure and draw straight lines builds on the basic skill of drawing straight lines with a straight edge.
Performing specific geometric constructions requires skillful use of the compass to draw arcs and circles accurately.
Performing specific geometric constructions requires accurate drawing of straight lines using a straight edge.
Performing specific geometric constructions requires measuring lengths and drawing lines precisely using a ruler.
Performing specific geometric constructions requires measuring and constructing angles accurately using a protractor.
Performing specific geometric constructions requires drawing perpendicular and parallel lines accurately using a set square.
Understanding terms such as theorem, proof, axiom, and corollary is necessary to investigate and prove theorems related to ratios.
Proving theorems concerning ratios lays the foundation for understanding and applying the Pythagorean theorem in right-angled triangles.
Applying trigonometric ratios in right-angled triangles requires prior understanding of the Pythagorean theorem to relate side lengths.
Recognizing linear equations in standard form requires understanding coordinate systems and how points are represented numerically.
Using slope to determine parallelism requires knowledge of coordinate plane and how slope is calculated from coordinates.
Using slope to determine perpendicularity depends on understanding the coordinate plane and slope concept.
Calculating triangle area from coordinates requires understanding how points are represented in the plane numerically.
The sine rule extends trigonometric reasoning from right-angled to any triangle.
The cosine rule generalizes trigonometric calculations to any triangle using side lengths and included angles.
The double angle formula for cosine uses the Pythagorean identity relating sine and cosine squares.
Expressing cosine squared in terms of cosine double angle depends on the double angle formula.
Expressing sine squared in terms of cosine double angle depends on the double angle formula.
Proof by contradiction is a deductive reasoning method used to establish mathematical truths.
Determining parallelism using slope requires understanding logical implications and definitions.
Determining perpendicularity using slope relies on logical relationships between slopes.
Solving systems of linear equations involves finding points of intersection graphically or algebraically.
Students first use tables to represent repeating-pattern situations and linear relationships before plotting these relationships graphically to visualize them as straight lines.
Understanding linear graphs allows students to interpret the slope as the rate of change of the dependent variable with respect to the independent variable.
Once students understand slope as rate of change, they can interpret the y-intercept as the start value or initial condition in a linear relationship.
Plotting linear relationships graphically enables students to find the point where two lines intersect, representing the solution to a system of equations.
